answerText: EPR spectroscopy [or Electron Paramagnetic Resonance spectroscopy; or Electron Spin Resonance spectroscopy; or Electron Magnetic Resonance spectroscopy][10] EPR spectroscopy is used to study these molecules that are formed by homolytic cleavages. Fremy's salt is an example of these highly reactive molecules that have unpaired electrons.
heading: VCU Closed |2013 | Harvard A and Virginia B | 13 | Science | Chemistry | College
subject: Science
question: Question: Splittings in this type of spectroscopy have much higher energies than those in NMR. For 10 points each: [10] Name this type of spectroscopy that typically uses microwave radiation to excite the spin of unpaired electrons that are placed in a magnetic field.
